Bridge to Psalm 43
My prayer for us as we look at Psalm 43 this

167.text:
evening is that God would encourage us to
honour him in times of trial by both being

174.text:
real about our suffering and fully trusting
him – like Roger Carswell.

181.text: Turn with me to Psalm 43. Let’s pray.

193.text:
Father God, you know our trials. You know
that trusting you is a struggle because we

201.text:
suffer, we face opposition, we can’t see
you and our hearts are slow to take comfort

209.text:
from your promises. Please speak to us through
this Psalm, encourage us and strengthen our

216.text:
trust in you through our trials.
In Jesus’ name, Amen.

A recent example of this is the Scottish nurse

Council.

The charge was that she knowingly allowed
a wrong temperature to be recorded when she

returned to the UK after treating Ebola patients
in Sierra Leone.

308.text:
The charges hung over her for 2 years, but
then she was vindicated.

everyone sees that God is right – and he

cooly and calmly over a cup of hot chocolate
lying on the sofa watching the Great British

Bake Off with his slippers on! No! He prays

Vindicate me….
2 For you are the God in whom I take refuge;

why have you rejected me?
Why do I go about mourning

He cries out for vindication precisely because

401.text:
Situations where we may feel like we’re
in Psalm 43

406.text:
Maybe that’s you at the moment: you’re
trusting God, facing opposition for your faith

412.text:
in Jesus and desperately seeking vindication.
I remember one time when I felt this very

424.text:
strongly.
A few years back, I was accepted to be a Reach

429.text:
Volunteer with Friends International in Exeter
to befriend and share the Gospel with international

436.text:
students.
As part of that year, I needed to raise financial

441.text:
support to cover living costs, which was daunting.
However, one morning, I read Philippians chapter

448.text:
4 and I was particularly encouraged by v.19
– And my God will meet all your needs according

452.text:
to his glorious riches in Christ Jesus. I
was persuaded that God had promised to meet

459.text:
my financial needs and that he would do so.
The difficulty was that some of relatives

468.text:
felt that I was being foolish. They couldn’t
get their heads around why I had to ask for

473.text:
money. And they didn’t feel that I would
raise the money I needed.

477.text:
And so there I was – being faithful to God
– but feeling foolish for God – in front

485.text:
of people who didn’t trust in God. And I
tell you what I wanted!

490.text:
Vindication! Vindication! I wanted them to
see that God was a God who provided – and

498.text:
that I was right to trust in him – and that
they should too. I cried out for vindication!

506.text:
I don’t know what situations you might be
in where you cry out for vindication.

514.text:
I talked there about money. What about relationships?
A work colleague says to you:

520.text:
“You were crazy to turn down that guy’s
offer of a date. You guys would be great together.

526.text:
Why do you keep holding out hope for a Christian
husband/wife – or for singleness? I feel

533.text:
sorry for you.”
Or a neighbour says to you:

536.text:
“You’re retired and you’re busier now
than two years ago! Why do give so much time

543.text:
and energy to offering hospitality to random
people, or helping in the church? I know that’s

548.text:
probably a Christian thing. But if you don’t
do what you really want to do with your retirement,

554.text:
you’re losing out!”
In those situations, we burn for vindication.

561.text:
Vindication. Vindication.
We want God to show everyone that his way

566.text:
is best – and that we are right to trust
him – and we want him to do it now!

571.text:
Cry out to God for vindication
Yet the difficult thing is that vindication

577.text:
rarely happens straight away – we have to
hold on to God’s promises while we’re

584.text:
in the dark.
For example, for me with that Friends International

593.text:
post, that meant several months of testing
until God provided all the finances I needed.

598.text:
And my relatives saw that God provided.
But it may well take even longer than that

603.text:
– and not be complete.
One thinks of the Christians in Iraq who have

607.text:
suffered so much in recent years for their
faith. Recently I read that an important Iraqi

614.text:
Shia leader had spoken out in their favour.
Despite having suffered greatly, he said that

622.text:
Christians had never responded with violence
and had continued to promote unity. That’s

629.text:
some measure of vindication for Iraq’s suffering
Christians.

635.text:
But sometimes vindication will not happen
this side of heaven.

640.text:
Many of us will know of the Christian registrar
Lilian Ladelle. In 2006 she wrote to her employer

649.text:
asking for a reasonable accommodation of her
religious objection to same-sex civil partnerships.

655.text:
Her employer refused. She took her case to
the employment tribunal and won. Then that

660.text:
verdict was overturned. She took her case
to the European Court of Human Rights which

664.text:
ruled against her. And then in 2013 she had
nowhere to appeal to. Then she died in 2015

676.text:
with a clear conscience before God, but black
marks in the eyes of many...

682.text:
…so where is vindication for Lilian Ladelle?
Friends be assured that vindication will come!

692.text:
You – and I – and Lillian Ladelle will
get justice!

Conclusion

1265.text:
So friends, what will you do when you face
severe trials like Roger Carswell did?

1275.text:
Option 1. Glibly hold onto truths in the Bible
which you don’t feel are true.

1289.text:
Option 2. Spiral into spiritual despair because
you lose sight of God’s promises.

1302.text:
Option 3. Follow the example of the Psalmist
– and Roger Carswell – and Jesus! Wrestle

1312.text:
with God! Pour out your heart to him! Ask
him for vindication! Ask him for light! Look

1323.text:
forward to heaven! Keep wrestling with him!
Through Psalm 43, God is pleading with each

1333.text:
of one of us to choose option 3.
Let’s pray.

who speak your truth, but don’t believe

promises. Help us instead to wrestle with

1360.text:
